												If you love old school type action shooters such as Battleships or 1942 then you're going to love Battle Group 2 as it combines the best of those, it's so easy to just pick up and play with no complicated controls or instructions and with minimal setup as well so you'll be up and playing in a couple of minutes. In fact it's such a breeze that any fool can play it.This is strictly a single player game with 30 stages in the campaign and starts off very easy and gets progressively more difficult with each stage that you complete, there are no difficulty options so everyone plays the same game. Each stage is very short and your job is to control a single ship at the start and two ships after your have upgraded to fend off various waves of planes and helicopters which can be shot down with your ships guns or missiles which can also be upgraded at the end of every stage when your scores and rewards are displayed. You control a primary ship which is your main weapon and a support ship which offers backup and there are a total of 8 ships that you can collect and use throughout the game.Ok graphics and sound i have to say is really quite impressive, really nice detail in the sea which flows quite nicely and all the ships behave as they should but the sound is far more impressive, guns have a real nice meaty sound as they should and the planes also sound very good and they do sound like jets too. The voice overs for the story content is nicely done and there are some good background voices too for the ships, the controls are really so easy and all you have to worry about is moving the mouse to aim at the targets and then the mouse button to fire your weapons.This is a very casual game so you can play it as much or as little as you like, it's just a great load of fun but it's very addictive i can tell you !! Depending on how well you do in any given stage you are rewarded with a number of stars so reach 90% of your goal on that stage and you'll be rewarded with 3 stars and get over 100% and you'll receive 4 stars but they are golden so can you collect all the stars? Some stages although not all that difficult will leave you pulling your hair out especially if you want all those golden stars, sometimes i found myself on 99% and thought there's no way i can do that but your will keep trying until you get there.In summary just ask yourself do you like planes and ships and want a good fun time without reading loads of instructions or have a long winded tutorial or without needing to know what you have to do to get any where? If that all sounds good to you then you could do a lot worse than boot this baby up, oh and by the way there is more content to come and the Developers are rather active in the community and are a friendly bunch of souls so why not give it a go? I personally rate it a rather good 82/100 but that may improve after more content arrives but have fun playing the game.

VERDICT: Battle Group 2 can best be described as a naval-themed strategy clicker, on-rails.  Take one or two ships, survive thirty-one naval patrols by destroying enemy planes, ships and missiles while keeping  your kill streak alive.  Gain rewards to upgrade and unlock better ships.  Its simple premise, fast-paced gameplay and short quick-fire sessions are sure to take you back to playing Missile Command back in the day.  The challenge is pretty easy, though gameplay is quite addictive.  Graphics are well-drawn and the music though simple, suits the pace of the game perfectly. Reservations include not so dynamic enemy spawns and pathing.  It gets grindy towards the end.  There is no endless mode and it could really do with more content with more ships, more weapons, more levels and even more action! Other than that despite its mobile/tablet origins, it was actually a fun port to play and is sure to be a draw for fans of casual games. ... More info below ...01. GENRE: Arcade/Clicker Action-Shooter.02. SETTING: Naval Warfare operations.04. GAME MODES: Singleplayer with one thirty-one level campaign.05. GAME/LEVEL DESIGN: So-called replayable missions but low randomness.  Missions can be replayed if failed.06. GAMEPLAY/MECHANICS: Guide your ships to the end of the level and blast every enemy seen as your fleet moves horizontally across the screen without player input.  Point and click to shoot weapons or approaching missiles.  Your ships have numerous fixed weapons and anti-fire measures such as: missiles, cannons, helicopters, flares or anti-missile guns.   Maintaining high kill-streaks provide bonus oil barrels and raises your score.  A few Boss encounters are littered through the missions.  The action is in real-time.  Timing is everything.   Better ships can be unlocked with oil barrels earned by shooting enemy aircraft, missiles, installations and ships.  Three power-ups can be purchased to assist you: Hyper-time - slows down time, EMP Blast - clears enemy missiles and Instant Recharge - circumvents the reload time.  07. ENEMIES: There are a limited number of enemies, each with their own particular traits.  Kamikaze gunboats move slowly but zig-zag to avoid your fire.  Frogfoot sub-sonic planes fly slower and shoot projectiles while their Mig-type counterparts fly faster and fire homing rockets.  Forcing players to concentrate on where and when they fire.  Rockets provide a slow moving target but are fired in large numbers.  While helicopters hover and fire multiple times before fleeing off-screen.  Periodically you will see bonus aircraft.  These are harder to destroy but provide a good amount of bonus are help maintain kill-streaks.08. A.I: Basic but well implemented.  Mostly due to the fact that the A.I. doesnt have to react to anything.  The illusion of a clever enemy is conjoured through the use of varied flight-paths/pathing, increased numbers, speed of movement and spawn frequency.  However its all done very well and you never quite feel in control in the final missions.  Something I imagine is intentional so iOS users spend cash on power-ups.  PC users at least wont need to worry.  (Earn enough to buy power-ups by farming oil, by repeating missions)09. INTERFACE/CONTROLS: Very simple and robust.  Just mouse click on the target to shoot, use ships secondary equipment or activate a power-up.  Its not to hard to see why this was made for iOS.10. GRAPHICS: Pristine, clean-cut and great for this sort of game.  From the detailed artwork of each of the four primary and secondary support ships to the enemy air and seacraft, all of it is pretty to look at.  As are the explosions!  Changes to ships when damaged by enemy fire is neat.  As are the animations when you fail to protect them and they sink.11. SOUNDTRACK & AUDIO: Very good.  Music changes depending on the mood of the action from soft mellow _ to hard pulsating eletro rock tones when you are up against it!  Simulated battle chatter takes the overall audio experience from being good to just that bit more!12. VOICE ACTING: Very good again.  It has an excellently voiced female commander/co-pilot to help you through the first few missions which I thought was actually well-written and voiced.  Thought there isnt enough of it and during my playthrough she isnt used as much in the final third of the game.  Which is a shame.13. CHALLENGE/DIFFICULTY:  Difficulty is very low to barely moderate.  The real challenge is slanted towards getting perfect or near perfect scores using high kill-streaks.  Given the speed of the moving craft, their numbers and frequency this becomes near impossible in some missions, especially towards the end.  For mere mortals like me the availability of the power-ups makes life much simple!  Overall the recipe is simple: Choose the right ships.  Have enough upgrades and power-ups and the game ceases to be much of a challenge and devolves into a click-fest!  14. PROBLEMS: None experienced.15. ACHIEVEMENTS: Possesses a good mix of achievements overall.  Complete campaign missions, use x type of power-ups, unlock y number of ships or earn n mission stars.  Achieve milestones such as: shoot z missiles, hit m targets etc.  Most are obtainable in a few hours.  Only a two; kill 10,000 targets, shoot 10,000 missile need a fair amount of grinding.16. DLC: None.17. ONLINE PLAY/COMMUNITY: Singleplayer only.18. ENJOYMENT/APPEAL: BG2 provides a good dose of fast and easily accessible shooting, blasting fun that may get somewhat old after about half-way.  It did for me.  19. PLAYTIME/LONGEVITY/REPLAYABILITY:  The campaign can be completed in  five or so hours if you are efficient with your oil spending and get the ships you need rather than the highest ranked ones. You will have to be smart and grind out credits to purchase power-ups.  If you want 100% achievements then you will need to grind alot.  Doing so will extend the game life to at least ten hours.  More if you aren't fussed at getting perfect scores every time.20. VALUE FOR MONEY: Its on sale quite frequently. Just about worth the full price, if your budget allows or you cant wait for a sale.

You are in control of two ships, a primary vessel geared towards attacking and a secondary vessel with a variety of support options.The game's story is Command and Conquer with you playing as the UN versus NOD, for some reason. There are some gimmicks in levels, such as your vessels getting split up, having to defend civilians and night battles but its really the same thing again and again. At least for me, the combat was satisfying because of that delay and it is satisfying to blow up enemies and watch the debris fall into the water.The sound design is steller. You get nice ambient radio chatter, satisfying explosion sounds and distinctive noise made by each enemy and missle type. On the whole, I'd say its a nice short arcade blaster worth its budget price.

												Make no mistake, this certainly isn't a terrible game, but I've played better, and it's got a lot to do with how it's only difficult due to poor design choices.Simply put, those new ships and upgrades you can buy and upgrade over the course of the game? Not optional. Not in the slightest. You're going to notice early on that your performance is kind of hamstrung by the fact that ALL of your ships have an absolutely abysmal reload rate, and the only way you're going to remotely keep up with the increasing onslaughts that the enemies throw at you is to upgrade your clip sizes and reload rates to the max as early on as you can - and when I say reload rate, I don't mean the reload rates for your main gun, which you cannot upgrade the reload rate of by any means.Well, that's not so bad, you may say, doesn't that add to the challenge of the game?It does. Right up until you start realizing that you are literally having too many enemies and missiles thrown at you to shoot down unless you buy a lot of expensive single-use powerups, and I mean expensive as in "you will have to grind entire early-to-mid-game missions at least once to buy a single pack of the only truly useful one", and that's not even factoring what it's going to take to get the late-game ships and upgrades that, again, you're absolutely going to NEED in order to stand a chance.Basically, you can't beat this game without grinding like crazy, and that's not challenging. It's a timesink and nothing more. It's really too bad, because there's really not much wrong with the game itself - it's simple, good, lead-the-target fun that allows you the chance to negate all damage if you're quick and accurate enough... at least until the game starts throwing too much at you to handle without the need for powerups. I did beat the game, but I didn't four-star every mission, and the ending isn't worth it. I have my doubts that 100%ing the game is worth the time it'll take to beat it, and I personally can't recommend this game unless you wait for a rather hardcore discount; it's not worth eight dollars.

												      A simple point and click naval wargame that delivers an enjoyable, albeit simple, experience. The game boasts some very nice graphics (especially the warships) and some interesting sound design (especially in the menus), and is overall a fun, small game. If you want something that looks like Capcom's 1942, (I bought the game solely because it reminded me of custom naval units like the Arm Yamato for Total Annihilation back in the day), and plays as simply as your average tower defense game, you might enjoy this game. There is some nice music, but not enough of it. After the first few missions the game doesn't really change too much, but unlocking ships (with their unique weapons) is a rewarding enough reason to keep playing.       I recommend this game, but I'd add the caveat that only if it appeals to you, and if it is on sale.
